We observe that the Richmond Enquirer exult'
nightly at the result OF the late election in the
State OF Ncw-Ynrk. and seens ready 10 boast TINT
the combinations are at last completed that. having
majority in the Legislature. the party OF Mess,s.
Van Buren,, Clinton, aud Coleman. will take the
election of Electors out Of the hand. OF the People
into their own. Our friends at Rchmond are pre-
mature in their rejoicing. Nobody, not even the
Editors OF the Enquirer believes that THE PEOPLE
of New York are opposed to the present Admins
tration. They are duped-d observation-disclosures. IN
regard to the late election 1t yet possible, howe
ver that they are safe. 1t is yet possible that The
popular branch Of the Legislature will contain ma
jorty of the friends Of law. Of peace abroad, and
of tranquility at home of free trade on the ocean,
and OF civil authority On the land. We are not
certain ot the fact. but we incline to believe that
what we know to be pOssble, in this case, is also
true.

DR.. Emmons. of this town. was called in. and the

and ingenious, and may be Of use IN similar cases II

the pin, were it absorbed moisture. aud became 81,

We have seen gentleman this morning from the
interior Of Ncw-York, who assures Us that the recent
election forms just criterion ojudge Of the senti-
ments of the People on the Presidential question
that it Is the result of combination Of circum-
set in motion by the party machinery of the Master
Spirit who has heretofore been successful in control
ing majority Of members of the Legislature, but
defeated IN the Presidential vote. Our informant
further states, that when the People called upon
to vote upon the single question, Adan's Jackson.
next fall, there cannot be doubt of Mr.. ADAMS
obtaining most signal triumph, as more than three
fourths of the People are forhim Gen. jackson lav.
ing no other popularity than what is forced up by
the bargain between Van Buren andCiinton, for
their own private advancement.
NEW YORK.
From The baltimore Patriot.

Considerable excitement has been for some time
past, visible Oh our Northern frontier, in conse-
quence of the disposition exhibted by the inhab-
tants Of Canada aud Nova Scotia to interrupt and
injure American citizens settling on the territory
which ntervenes between Canada and New Bruns-
wick, and to interfere with our right to take fish,
and to land on the Magtialcn islands for the purpose
of curing them. As relates to settlers on the
territory, the possession Of which is disputed BY the
Canadians, force seems to have been resorted to
FOR the purpose Of expelling American citizens, and
one of our fellow citizens is said to have been ar
rested under process from a Canadian magistrate,
and actually conveyed to prison and subjected to
trial and fine. This is to be regretted, because
it has tendency to produce i'll will, and desire
of retaliation, which ought to be avoided on every
account. We have given in our last paper extracts
from the treaties of Paris and Of Client to show
what is the boundary line as described therein.-
Commissioners were appointed to have the line sur
veyed and settled. lhere is no dispute as to the
real course of the boundary but Great Britain is
desirous to correct the mistake she made in conced-
ing the territory which lies Immediately between
Canada and New Brunswick. and subjects all in.
tercourse between them to a tedious and crcutous
route, unless it be carried on through the Ame-
rican territory. But the difference the subject


is for the discussion and decision of the governments
and not of individuals who may choose to decide tor


themselves to the value Of the territory, and as to


the means possessing themselves of it. The nhabl-


ants Of that part Of Canada lying contiguous to the
claimed territory are very eager. and apparently
very determined, to seize and possess it. laws and
treaties equity and moral obligation. to the contra
ry Notwithstanding. But we hope the British go
vernnent will deem it right to repress this dispos-
tion. and not to sanction acts which must of necessity
provoke retaliation from the individuals who cons
der themselves nsulted and injured


AS to our practice Of curing fish on the Magda
len islands, which has also excited the dsp!easure
of some Of our neighbours. we have also taken pains
to lay before readers the article of the
ton Of 1878 by which it is secured to us for con-
sideraon on our part whichis therein expressed. 1t


is right conceded to US forever and il the supe-
rlor industry and enterprise Of our fishermen has
been such as to excite the envy and i'll will Of theil
competitors. it is ungenerous in the latter to resort
to onplalnts Of outrages which have NJ foundation
in truth, with view to defeat that success which
! they unable to subdue by fair rivalry. Like
the disputes in Canada. we are bound to believe that


thes also are confined to persons who are ignorant
OF the stipuatinns Of the convention on the subject
and that the British government will not be back


ward in repressing that spirit Of opposition TO Ane


rcan interests and proceedings which are in no wise


contrary to the splritot existing treaties.

NEW YORK ELECTION RErURNS.-it is
impossible to give accurate statement Of the re-
suit of the election in the different counties Of the
state. In most of the counties the election has been
conducted with reference to local matters and with


out regard to the Presidential election. We howe
yer give the following list Of members elect, who are
known to be friendly to the administration, and ac-
corting to our best belief and knowledge it is cor
rect, and as we become further acquainted with the
sentiments of the members Of the next Legislature

SlLK.-Janes Wo'sston, Esq. Of Marlborough.

this season.--rhey made from about 800 worms,
400 skeins. For evenness OF thread and decacy

with Italian or French silk. Some have supposed,
that feeding the silkworm could not be profitable.
until intricate machinery and rare skill in the man
utacture Of silk goods. should be introduced here
1t is not so: near million Of dollars year of the

abnndantiy' manufactures will rise up, Of course.

The Utica (Oneida) Sentinel holds the following
language in respect TO the late election, which
firms entirely the sentiments advanced by Sat
urday:


Ofone thing, however, the public ought to be cor
rectly informed. the Presidential question did
not form the dividing line in this county, in fact
any where at the west of us. We are aware that
the Jacksonlans will use every exer!ion to create an
impression that question governed the electors, and
that the result is fair test Of the strength of the
friends OF Adams and of Jackson. Every body
here. however. knows better and we contradict
the assertion merely To prevent mistakes abroad.
Next fall. when the Presidential electors are to be
chosen, the ballot boxes will show that this county,
and the west generally, are almost unanimously in
favor "f the present administration. and the cause
of public improvements domestic industry, national
prosperity, and civil order.

valuable foreign plants in the United States is
made public, in the hope that the object which it
has in view may be the better promoted by causing
it to be more generally known.

TCIRCULAR.1


TREASURY DEPARTMENT,


September, 8, 1897.
Sir The President is desirous of causing to be
introduced into the United States all such trees and
plants from other countries, not heretofore known in
the United States as may give promise, under pro-
per guilty alton, of hourishiny and becoming useful
as well AS superior varieties OF such are already
cultivated here. TO this end have his directions
90 address myself to you, invoking your and TO give
effect to the plan that he has in view. Forest trees
useful for timber grain OF any description; vegc.
tables for the table esculent roots and IN short.
plants of whatever nature whether useful as food
for man or the domestic animals, or for purposes
connected with manufactures or any of the useful
arts, fall within the scope Of the plan proposed.
specification of Of them, to be had in the coun-
try where you reside, and believed to fall under one
or other of the above heads, is given at the foot Of
this letter. as samples merely, it not being intended
TO exclude others, of which you may yourself have
knowledge, or be able, on inquiry. to obtain knowl
edge. With any that you may have it in your power
10 send it will be desirable TO send such notices OF
their cultivation and natural history may be at
tanable in the country to which they are Indigenous
and the following questions are amongst those that
will indicate the particulars concerning which inor-
nation may be sought


/. The latitude and soil in which the plant most
hourishes.


g. What are the seasons of its bloom and maturi.
ty, and what the term of its duration


3. In what manner is it Propagated BY roots,
seeds, buds, gratis layers, or how ! and how cul.
tivated and are there any unusual circumstances
attending its cultivation


4. Is it affected by frost, in countries where frost
prevails


s. The native or popular name Of the plant and
(where known) its botanical name and character.
g. The elevation Of the place Of its growth above
the level of the sea.


T. Is there n the agricultural literature of the
country, any special treatise dissertation upon its
culture If so let If be stated


g. Is there any insect particularly habituated to
ii


8. Lastly---its use, whether for food, medicine,
or the arts.


In removing seeds OF plants from remote places
across the ocean, or otherwise, great care is often
necessary to be observed in the manner of putting
them up and conveying them. To aid your efforts
in this respect, upon the present occasion, paper
otdirections has been prepared and is herewith
transmitted


The President will hope for your attention to The
objects of this communication as far circum-
stances will allow and it is not doubted but that yonr
own public feelings will impart to your endeavour.
under it, zeal proportioned to the beneficial results
to which the communication looks. 1t is proper tc
add that no expense can at present be authorised ir
relation to it. 1t is possible however, that Congress:
may not be indsposed to provide Il small fund fol
il. The seeds, plants, cuttings, or whatever othe
terminating substance you may transmit must b,
addressed to the Treasury Department, and sen
TO the Collector of the port to which the vesse
conveying them is destined, or where she may ar
rive, accompanied bya letter Of advice to the De
partment. The Secretary the Navy has instruct
ed the Commanders of such of the public vessel
of the United States as may ever touch at Your port
70 lend you their assistance towards giving effect
the objects of this communication as you will per
ceive by the copy Of his letter of instruction.
which is herewith enclosed for your information
is believed also, that the Masters of the merchar
vessels of the United States will generally be will
ing-such is their we'll known public spirt-.-to len
their gratuitons cooperation towards effectnc III
objects proposed.


remain, respectfully, your most obedient ser'v


RICHARD RUSH.

one of our fellow citizens is said to have been ar
rested under process from a Canadian magistrate,
and actually conveyed to prison and subjected to
trial and fine. This is to be regretted, because
it has tendency to produce i'll will, and desire
of retaliation, which ought to be avoided on every
account. We have given in our last paper extracts
from the treaties of Paris and Of Client to show
what is the boundary line as described therein.-
Commissioners were appointed to have the line sur

real course of the boundary but Great Britain is

tercourse between them to a tedious and crcutous

is for the discussion and decision of the governments
and not of individuals who may choose to decide tor


themselves to the value Of the territory, and as to


the means possessing themselves of it. The nhabl-

claimed territory are very eager. and apparently
very determined, to seize and possess it. laws and

provoke retaliation from the individuals who cons

AS to our practice Of curing fish on the Magda

of some Of our neighbours. we have also taken pains
to lay before readers the article of the
ton Of 1878 by which it is secured to us for con-

is right conceded to US forever and il the supe-
rlor industry and enterprise Of our fishermen has
been such as to excite the envy and i'll will Of theil
competitors. it is ungenerous in the latter to resort
to onplalnts Of outrages which have NJ foundation
in truth, with view to defeat that success which
! they unable to subdue by fair rivalry. Like

thes also are confined to persons who are ignorant
OF the stipuatinns Of the convention on the subject
and that the British government will not be back


ward in repressing that spirit Of opposition TO Ane


rcan interests and proceedings which are in no wise


contrary to the splritot existing treaties.

conducted with reference to local matters and with


out regard to the Presidential election. We howe
yer give the following list Of members elect, who are
known to be friendly to the administration, and ac-
corting to our best belief and knowledge it is cor
rect, and as we become further acquainted with the

SlLK.-Janes Wo'sston, Esq. Of Marlborough.
was 80 kind as to bring for our Inspection last week
specimen of sewing silk, made by his daughters,
this season.--rhey made from about 800 worms,
400 skeins. For evenness OF thread and decacy
OF cuouring, it would bear favourable comparison
with Italian or French silk. Some have supposed,
that feeding the silkworm could not be profitable.
until intricate machinery and rare skill in the man
utacture Of silk goods. should be introduced here
1t is not so: near million Of dollars year of the
article IN the simple form of sewing silk-as east
iy made as shoe-thread-is annually innorted.
AS to the rest, if the raw material be produced
abnndantiy' manufactures will rise up, Of course.


BY the way, the Junior editor has still thousand
or two Of the Italian mulberry to give away They
are not large Beng Of this years growth, and cal
be taken IN ii ha"akerchiet. An hundred will b,
given to each person sending. The roots are fin,
and vigorous, Application should be made With,
two weeks, possible, at his garden, at Sprinryille


0 mile below the Borough.

full articles.headline: From the Ne,o Fork american.
full articles.article:
The Utica (Oneida) Sentinel holds the following
language in respect TO the late election, which
firms entirely the sentiments advanced by Sat
urday:


Ofone thing, however, the public ought to be cor
rectly informed. the Presidential question did
not form the dividing line in this county, in fact
any where at the west of us. We are aware that
the Jacksonlans will use every exer!ion to create an
impression that question governed the electors, and
that the result is fair test Of the strength of the
friends OF Adams and of Jackson. Every body
here. however. knows better and we contradict
the assertion merely To prevent mistakes abroad.
Next fall. when the Presidential electors are to be
chosen, the ballot boxes will show that this county,
and the west generally, are almost unanimously in
favor "f the present administration. and the cause
of public improvements domestic industry, national
prosperity, and civil order.


The Black Rock Gazette. Erie C0unty,) gives
the following result Of the election in that county
and district


THE Eiection.-The election in this county has
resulted in the choice of General Peter b. Porter,
and Colonel David Burt, of this town, to the Assem-
bly,, by large maorties.


1t is almost unnecessary to add that the members
elect are decided friends Of the general atministra-
ton. as none other could have been elected in this
county.


TH'uenda -" iiuCJ- Lsq. mas Deen clecfe0 10 Con-
gress, in the district composed Of Genesce and Or
leans counties. by about four Thousand majority =
His opponent. Mr.. isdale, was got up and sup
ported as the Jackson candidate. Mr. Tracy is a
decided friend OF the administration.


Timothy II. Porter, Esq. has been elected to the
Senate. from this district, without any organized
opposition. Mr.. Porter, is friend to the admins
tration.


| Av an advertisement in the New York Freedoms
Journal. Samuel f. Cornish, lately one of the Edi-
tors of that paper, offers for sale, to his cooure,l
brethren. two thousand of excellent land at
less than half its value, provided they will take
measures to settle or have it settled by coloured
farmers. The land is situated in the state of New
York, within 70 miles Of the city," &c.

. Of the City Of New York, having directed Monu

valuable foreign plants in the United States is
made public, in the hope that the object which it
has in view may be the better promoted by causing
it to be more generally known.
Copies of the circular have been placed in the
hands Of the principal collectors, ofwhom they may
be had by such masters of vessels. or others gons
abroad, may he willing to aid in carrying into ei
feet design believed To give promise OF public
utility.


TCIRCULAR.1


TREASURY DEPARTMENT,


September, 8, 1897.
Sir The President is desirous of causing to be
introduced into the United States all such trees and
plants from other countries, not heretofore known in
the United States as may give promise, under pro-
per guilty alton, of hourishiny and becoming useful
as well AS superior varieties OF such are already
cultivated here. TO this end have his directions
90 address myself to you, invoking your and TO give
effect to the plan that he has in view. Forest trees
useful for timber grain OF any description; vegc.
tables for the table esculent roots and IN short.
plants of whatever nature whether useful as food
for man or the domestic animals, or for purposes
connected with manufactures or any of the useful
arts, fall within the scope Of the plan proposed.
specification of Of them, to be had in the coun-
try where you reside, and believed to fall under one
or other of the above heads, is given at the foot Of
this letter. as samples merely, it not being intended
TO exclude others, of which you may yourself have
knowledge, or be able, on inquiry. to obtain knowl
edge. With any that you may have it in your power
10 send it will be desirable TO send such notices OF
their cultivation and natural history may be at
tanable in the country to which they are Indigenous
and the following questions are amongst those that
will indicate the particulars concerning which inor-
nation may be sought


/. The latitude and soil in which the plant most
hourishes.


g. What are the seasons of its bloom and maturi.
ty, and what the term of its duration


3. In what manner is it Propagated BY roots,
seeds, buds, gratis layers, or how ! and how cul.
tivated and are there any unusual circumstances
attending its cultivation


4. Is it affected by frost, in countries where frost
prevails


s. The native or popular name Of the plant and
(where known) its botanical name and character.
g. The elevation Of the place Of its growth above
the level of the sea.


T. Is there n the agricultural literature of the
country, any special treatise dissertation upon its
culture If so let If be stated


g. Is there any insect particularly habituated to
ii


8. Lastly---its use, whether for food, medicine,
or the arts.


In removing seeds OF plants from remote places
across the ocean, or otherwise, great care is often
necessary to be observed in the manner of putting
them up and conveying them. To aid your efforts
in this respect, upon the present occasion, paper
otdirections has been prepared and is herewith
transmitted


The President will hope for your attention to The
objects of this communication as far circum-
stances will allow and it is not doubted but that yonr
own public feelings will impart to your endeavour.
under it, zeal proportioned to the beneficial results
to which the communication looks. 1t is proper tc
add that no expense can at present be authorised ir
relation to it. 1t is possible however, that Congress:
may not be indsposed to provide Il small fund fol
il. The seeds, plants, cuttings, or whatever othe
terminating substance you may transmit must b,
addressed to the Treasury Department, and sen
TO the Collector of the port to which the vesse
conveying them is destined, or where she may ar
rive, accompanied bya letter Of advice to the De
partment. The Secretary the Navy has instruct
ed the Commanders of such of the public vessel
of the United States as may ever touch at Your port
70 lend you their assistance towards giving effect
the objects of this communication as you will per
ceive by the copy Of his letter of instruction.
which is herewith enclosed for your information
is believed also, that the Masters of the merchar
vessels of the United States will generally be will
ing-such is their we'll known public spirt-.-to len
their gratuitons cooperation towards effectnc III
objects proposed.


remain, respectfully, your most obedient ser'v


RICHARD RUSH.
